texts.text: I lean back against the wall of the smoking room and close my eyes.
I slowly take a drag of my cigarette and exhale.
I'm tired.
My eyelids feel heavy.
It's been two weeks since I started writing.
I completed the first draft this morning.
In the end, it took twice as long as I expected.
Yesterday, I wrote through the night.
I was gonna take a nap, but by the time I finished it was already time to leave for work.
I haven't slept well these last few weeks.
But I finished the first draft.
It's been years since I focused on writing like this.
As I lean there, the door opens and someone comes in.
I struggle to open my eyes and look toward the entrance.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Hey.
With his hand still on the sliding door, Watanabe stares at me.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: What is it?

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Mind if I come in?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Sure?
Watanabe sits next to me, pulls a packet of cigs out of his pocket, and pops one into his mouth.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Whoa, you bought your own?

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: I always have them on me, actually.
Instead of making a snappy comeback, I simply exhale a lungful of smoke.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: It's kind of hard to approach you these days.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Didn't even know if I should ask for a cig like I always do.
The comment makes me laugh out loud.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: What's so funny?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Nothing. It's just kinda funny to see you being so thoughtful.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: I'll have you know guys like me are awfully sensitive, you know?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I'm well aware, don't worry.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Then gimme one.
Chuckling, I hold out a cig for him.
He takes it, lights it, and looks a little more at ease by the time he huffs out the first puff of smoke.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...I was writing a novel.
He looks up at me, eyes wide open in surprise.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: A novel? Ah, right.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Every day for the last two weeks.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Oh, so that's what you've been up to.
I nod.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: And that's why you've been going around looking as grave as a tomb.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Apparently.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: I'm serious, man. You've had your head in the clouds for the last two weeks.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I finished the first draft.
Watanabe stares at me curiously.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Well, that's good.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: That doesn't mean it's complete yet.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: That's not what I meant.
I turn to him again.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: You felt like writing again, right?

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: You oughta do what you love.
I regard him in silence.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: I mean, you love books, right?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Yeah, I do.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I do love them.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: So what are you gonna do with this novel? Aren't there like, contests for that kind of stuff? To get published and all that.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Rookie awards, yeah. There's plenty of those.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: You wanna get it out there?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Nah.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: It's not that kind of novel.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I think the act of writing is meaningful in and of itself. Know what I mean?

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Hmm...
Smoke wafts from both our hands.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: So you won't let anyone read it? Kind of a shame after you've spent so much time and effort writing it.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: ...What about your wife?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...I wonder about that.
I stare vacantly at the rising smoke.
Rin's face comes to mind, as does my wife's.
Not as she looks right now, but how she looked back when we first met.
Classes are done for the day.
I go to the library for the first time in a good while.
I haven't talked to Rin since Watanabe words of caution.
Lately, the only space we've shared is the classroom.
I find her sitting at a table by the window reading a book.
She raises her face from it.
When she notices me, she directs a little smile at my way.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: It's been a while.
I nod.
She closes her book, the smile still on her face.
I sit down opposite her.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Another one of your dad's books?
She shakes her head.
She shows me the cover of the book.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Naoya Shiga?
She nods.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: That writer you said you like.
Didn't that conversation happen in a dream...?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: You told me when you showed me that old album.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: O-Oh, right. Yeah.
So I did tell her about it in real life.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I've been wanting to talk with you this whole time, but you never showed up.
I notice several other books by the same author next to her.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: How have you been?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I came to talk to you.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Was this occupied?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: It's fine. Go ahead.
She sets her book aside and neatly places her hands on her lap.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...You said you want to read what I write.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Yes.
She answers with a nod.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...I wrote something.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Would you read it?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Yes.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I'd like you to read it and tell me...
She tilts her head curiously and waits for me to continue.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: If Hatano Shuho and I... are at all similar.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: And if we are, I'd like to know in what way.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I want to hear it from you.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: That's why I wrote it.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I wrote about Hatano Shuho.
Rin squints at me for a moment.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Whether you and my dad are alike?
I stare at her in silence as she mutters the words to herself.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I wrote the story about the ginkgo.
Upon hearing this, she nods.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Ah...
Then she nods again and smiles.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: So it was you.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: You already realized?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: No.
She quirks a smile and puts a finger to her lower lip, deep in thought.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I see.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Huh?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: You already wrote what you want to show me, right?
I nod.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I finished the first draft this morning.
She nods back.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I'll revise it a little more.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Then I'd like for you to give it a read through.
She stares silently into my eyes.
After a moment, she speaks up again.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: When can I read it?
I think for a moment.
It's not a particularly long piece.
Today is Friday.
I can do some minimal tweaking to it over the weekend.
Even if I had more time, I can't just keep fixing stuff endlessly. It's important to let go.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I'll bring it first thing next week.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I'll be waiting.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Thank you.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: No, thank you.
I stand up.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: You're going home already?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I didn't sleep at all last night.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: My body's passing on the bill already. Time to pay with some sleep.
She rewards my silly comment with a little giggle.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Rest well.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I'll try.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: See you next week.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Yes.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I'm happy we got to talk again.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Bye.
I nod a farewell to her.
Just standing up makes my stomach feel like a piece of lead.
My body feels really close to giving out. My legs seem to be made of jelly.
I don't feel drowsy, but the fatigue is really piling on.
I turn on my laptop and open my manuscript file.
The printer purrs as I print out the draft I finished this morning.
After checking the first few pages to make sure there are no printing errors, I lay down on the bed.
I cover my eyes with my arm and sigh.
Then I take several slow, deep breaths.
With each exhale, my consciousness slowly drifts.
When I awake, the room is dark and the papers are all piled on the printer tray.
I pick them up and head to my desk.
Then I take a red pen from the pen holder.
I begin reading from the first sentence.
I use the red pen to delineate adjustments to the structure, wording, and punctuation.
I love editing.
It's much easier than writing, and I can better grasp the shape and texture of my words.
This is the image of Shuho the idol that I have inside my mind.
His outline is becoming clearer.
I continue from the prologue where he takes his first step as a professional writer, and progress into his life.
It's rife with change.
The protagonist is making a name for himself in the world of literature.
After winning his Rookie Award, he pumps out hit after hit, and receives the prestigious Akutagawa Prize for his third release.
He marries.
He sells his first million copies.
He gets his first film adaptation.
His media exposure increases exponentially.
As his life changed rapidly, he was pulled, molded, and made to grow by it.
From rags to riches. A tale as old as time.
Despite having written this myself, I must say that I find Shuho's story to be a real page-turner. It's like it's pulling me in.
I had no idea about his private life. Not really.
I was able to write about it once I dipped into the territory of fiction.
Reading this over, I realize once more.
The path Shuho followed was the ideal I wanted for myself once upon a time.
That desire for approval and recognition that I lost.
The withered desire to be in the spotlight.
Once upon a time, I had the same aspirations as him.
But I gave up, whereas he kept up the fight.
He fulfilled all of those young desires.
I wanted to live like he did.
I wanted the constant whirl of interactions and experiences he had. A life where you could see and do it all.
What did he see at the end?
What thoughts crossed his mind at the edge of death?
I can't imagine he had zero regrets.
I'm not young or gullible enough to take the persona he put up for the public at face value.
I had a list of the events of his life, and the impressions he left on his own flesh and blood, Rin.
I used those to piece together a picture of him and held it close to my heart.
In my own way, I depicted the inner world of a person who became an idol and was elevated to prominence.
A state of mind only those who fulfill their desires arrive at.
I'm sure a lot of people would be interested in this.
Here, I gave Shuho a human touch.
I depicted the frustrating experience of a divorce.
A latent distrust of women.
The existence of a daughter named Rin.
Despite his love for her, he dies without ever really knowing how to connect with his daughter.
And what he saw at the brink of life and death was...
The lost time with his family.
It takes me until midnight to finish the first round of corrections.
Now I have to actually apply the changes and print again.
I gather all the draft pages and place them in front of the laptop.
Over 100 sheets of A4 paper.
Some pages are a sea of bright red.
I have a lot of corrections to make.
The first draft is really not in a state to be shown to anyone just yet.
At this point, I still haven't managed to get the image in my mind fully out onto the paper.
Hopefully by the second draft I'll have the composition and writing that can convey what I'm trying to tell to the reader.
At least something good enough to get an impression of the structure from a third party.
Writing a first draft is like holding your breath underwater.
The second is a little easier to push out.
My concentration is a little off, but work goes apace.
When I've implemented about half the corrections, I take a break.
I still have Saturday and Sunday to get this done.
Then I can hand over the manuscript to Rin first thing Monday like I promised.
I raise my face from the screen and stretch my neck.
My bones make a satisfying popping noise.
My mind feels awfully clear. Maybe all the time spent awake in the dead of the night is affecting me.
My internal clock is getting messed up.
After our recent incident, my wife seems to feel even more awkward around me, so she's at home even less than before.
And it won't get any better. We're like two complete strangers at this point.
Still, right now it suits me to be alone in the house most of the time.
I decide to make myself a cup of coffee and keep working at it a while longer in the living room.
I'm roused by the sound of the living room door opening.
It looks like I passed out on the sofa.
Printed manuscript pages are scattered about the table in front of it.
I finished the rough revisions on Saturday, and I'm currently in the process of ironing out the little kinks.
The sound of the door heralds my wife's return.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Oh, you're back.

texts.name: Shouko
texts.text: Mhm.
She glances at the papers on the table.

texts.name: Shouko
texts.text: So you did it?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Yeah, kind of.

texts.name: Shouko
texts.text: Huh.
She stares at the manuscript for a while.

texts.name: Shouko
texts.text: You wrote what you wanted to write?
I think on the question.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I suppose... I also thought maybe it's what I need to write right nâ€”

texts.name: Shouko
texts.text: Maybe consider not letting anyone read it.
She cuts me off.
I simply look up at her in silence.

texts.name: Shouko
texts.text: I don't know if you can even do that, though.

texts.name: Shouko
texts.text: If you enjoyed writing what you want and it was worth something, you wouldn't be a teacher.
After thinking on that for a moment, I nod.

texts.name: Shouko
texts.text: Good thing you wrote your little piece. Well done.

texts.name: Shouko
texts.text: Good night.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...Good night.
By the time I squeeze out an answer, she's already closed the door behind her.
I don't think she's trying to be mean.
Nor do I think she was trying to throw cold water on my sudden desire to write.
I actually understand where she's coming from.
...She's absolutely right.
I stare at the scattered papers.
Is there any value to this story?
Maybe I'm too old to get my hopes up like this.
What will this manuscript change?
Nothing, that's what.
The whole time I was trying to become a writer, I was writing what I wanted.
And look how I ended up. Living a boring life, waiting for time to wash me away.
There's no way my writing can change someone's life.
I stare at the pages. There are over one hundred of them.
What's even the point of giving this to Rin?
But when I reach out to a page and begin to crumple it...

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I'd like to read what you write, though.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: When can I read it?
I stop myself.
I close my eyes.
Don't throw it all away.
You can't kick down what you built up with your own two hands.
No matter what my wife says.
No matter what anyone says.
Rin, and only Rin, said that she wanted to read my writing.
She said that she wanted to read something written by the person I am right now.
I open my eyes and breathe as I look down at the papers again.
Through this writing, I can face up to the image of Shuho within myself.
If it can help give Rin some insight somehow, it'll have some meaning.
And if she thinks it's not worth reading, she can just throw it away.
That's fine.
I'll give it to her and let her decide what to do with it.
I gather together all the scattered papers and go back to my room.
Monday is the day where I have the most classes to teach.
Rin is in my sixth period lecture today.
The last of the day, as it happens.
After finishing work, I'll head to the library.
I keep writing on the blackboard at a steady pace.
I continue giving my predetermined lecture.
My thoughts come to a standstill as I keep going right up until the bell chimes.
It's a part of the life I've been living for years.
As usual, I finish up the lecture, stop by the staff room, and go to the library.
I sit at a table by the window.
I gaze absently outside.
Just then, I spot Rin walking towards the library.
She looks up at me and smiles.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Did you finish it?
I give her a weak nod.
She cocks her head slightly to the side.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: If I give you this, it might be just an annoyance for you.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Why?
I spend a moment thinking of what to say.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...I just wonder if I'm in way over my head here. Doing something I shouldn't.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: My wife said something to me.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: She said that, if there was anything worthwhile in writing what I want to write, I wouldn't be here working as a professor.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Your wife? The editor?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Yeah.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: When she said that, I lost my motivation. I got scared.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Scared of having someone else read my writing.
Rin simply stares at me in silence

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...But I'm glad I wrote this. I mean that.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I started writing again because you said you wanted to read my writing.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Everything you've said to me since the day we first met has helped me face Shuho.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: The things I said?
I take the manuscript out of my bag and present it to Rin.
She stares at it, clearly surprised.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I wanted to see if I could help you, even a little. Since you said you wanted to know your dad.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: You wrote this for me?
I don't know how to answer.
It's true that's part of it.
I do want to help her somehow.
But wouldn't telling her that be too... compromising?
While thoughts race through my mind, she quietly reaches for the manuscript, and our hands touch.
Our fingers overlap atop the papers.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I'm really, really happy.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: It means a lot that you wrote this for me.
Still smiling sweetly, she lets go of my hand.
I can still feel her faint warmth on my skin.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Can I read it?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: If you want to.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I want to.
I nod.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...Thanks.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Will you wait while I read it?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Huh?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I'm not such a fast reader, though.
I nod.
Rin takes the manuscript and flips through the pages.
After watching her for a while, I turn my gaze out the window.
I attempt to read some books, but I'm unable to concentrate and end up simply waiting without doing much.
Rin's eyes meticulously glide over the letters.
By the time the sun starts setting, she's reached the last page.
She finishes reading and raises her face.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Now I understand how you feel about my father.
I nod.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: What did you want to achieve in this piece?
I simply stare at her in silence.
She looks down at the manuscript again.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: The person you described here is someone else, not my father.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: So what do you really want to achieve here?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Do you really want to depict my father?
Unsure how to answer, I simply stare at her.
She slowly shakes her head.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I'm asking because I believe you can write.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: You're a very fragile person. More so than you think.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: You can still turn back.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: But you've already started writing.
She lays a hand against my cheek.
I'm left stunned and speechless.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: You need to choose.
As she speaks, she stares directly into my eyes.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: If you want to write a real novel and depict a real person...

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: If you are prepared to depict real humans...
She trails off, then writes something on a piece of paper.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Come here after classes are done tomorrow.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: ...I'll be waiting.
With that, Rin stands up and walks away without looking back.
She left the manuscript on the table.
I'm overcome by an indescribable sense of helplessness and defeat.
I've never felt this way before.
I don't really remember what happened between the library and getting home.
The next thing I know, I'm staring at the ceiling of the living room in darkness.
If you are prepared to depict a human...
Her words keep echoing in my head.
What did she mean?
She might as well have said that what I wrote wasn't a depiction of a real person.
It would have been easier to swallow if she just said it was boring.
I close my eyes.
I feel a combination of defeat and regret.
The emotions seep into my chest and coat my very core.
I brush my fingers over my cheek.
Rin's hand touched my cheek today.
She laid her hand on top of mine.
I feel a phantom heat in the places where she touched me.
That was before Rin read my novel.
She must have been looking forward to reading it, only to be met with disappointment. Tends to happen when it comes to me.
My work, my effort...
That messy manuscript left on the desk of the library is all the proof I need
She deemed it unnecessary. She discarded it like trash.
Yet I cannot keep my mind from the faint warmth of her hand.
I was ridiculed.
I wish that heat would burn everything down so I can stop thinking.
Me and my writing. Put down like garbage in a can.
Just then, I hear a noise at the front door.
I hear the sound of shoes coming off by the entrance, followed by approaching footsteps.

texts.name: Shouko
texts.text: Why are the lights off? What are you doing?
My wife puts her bag on the table by the sofa and walks to the sink.
She's inadvertedly put her bag on top of my scattered manuscript.
Out of the bag sticks a creased, brown envelope.
I extend my arm and take it.
I don't recognize the author of the work inside of it.
I stare at the words absent-mindedly.
Until I hear fast approaching footsteps, and Shouko swipes the manuscript out of my hands.
I slowly turn my face to look up at her.
She looks down at me, her expression one of subdued fright.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Is that from the writer who was here the other day?
She merely frowns, offering no answer.
A trickle of wry laughter escapes my lips.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Have you been been drinking?
I look up at her, a corner of my mouth curling into a smirk.
She keeps staring at me, dumbfounded.
I notice the slight flush in her cheeks.
She's never been able to hold her drink very well.
I see the distrust in her eyes as her expression darkens.
How dare she look down on me like this?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I'm your husband, aren't I? What're you giving me that look for?

texts.name: Shouko
texts.text: What?
As she takes a step back, I get up and approach her.
She lets out a small breath, and with it comes the distinct smell of alcohol.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Why do I have to put up with everything, huh?!
Something in my head snaps, and I seize my wife by her shoulders.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Why do I have to put up with all this shit?! Why am I wasting my life here when no one even wants me?!

texts.name: Shouko
texts.text: Wha... Stop it! Get off!

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: You're my fucking wife!
Not heeding her cries, I pull her towards me.
A strange scent hits my nose as soon as she's closer.
It's not the smell of her perfume.
It's the scent of another man.
I laugh cruelly.
She holds her breath, looking up at me with terror lacing her pupils.
What the hell am I doing?
What even is my life anymore?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Tell me! What did I do to deserve this?!

texts.name: Shouko
texts.text: G-Get off me! Stop!
Paying no mind to my wife's protests, I push her down onto the sofa.

texts.name: Shouko
texts.text: Hey! Knock it off! It hurts! Ugh!
I lean over her back and pin her down.

texts.name: Shouko
texts.text: N-No! D-Don't!

texts.name: Shouko
texts.text: What are you even doing?! What's wrong with you?!
All I see in my head is Rin.
I feel the burning desire to touch her.
I want to make that delicate body mine.
I want to... become one with her.
A sense of disgust and inferiority sticks to me like ink.
Driven by that sick desire, I strip her clothes off.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I have no other way...
For the first time in decades, my wife's body seems alluring to me.
She's kept herself in good condition... to roll around in bed with some young writer.
Though I do have memories of us doing it for the sole purpose of making a kid once upon a time.
In this very house.
But this is different.
Time has changed it all.
Her protests peter out in time, turning into recalcitrant hatred.
This is very much like a microcosm of our marriage.
Such are the thoughts racing in my head as I desperately force myself upon her in an attempt to drown out Rin.
She quickly regains her breath, gets up, and directs a glare at me.

texts.name: Shouko
texts.text: You bastard...
She spits out a last insult before swiftly picking up her underwear and going to the restroom.
She slams the living room door behind her.
I stare at the scattered papers still laying on the table.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...I wanted you to read it too.
Without even thinking, I mutter at nothing.
The words trickle off my lips, destined to never reach anyone's ears.
I was young.
And so was she.
Back then, we took our lives for granted.
When did it become so difficult and painful?
We used to say what we meant.
We were vulnerable in front of each other.
Once upon a time, we were a real couple.
With a heavy sigh, I sink into the couch.
I turn my face up to the ceiling and cover my eyes with my right hand.
Tears slowly make their way down my face, rolling down my cheeks one after the other.
I've fallen the lowest a person can go.
I'm so pathetic and disgusting that I make myself laugh.
I wanted to be someone.
Like Hatano Shuho was.
Someone who would have recognition.
I didn't want to become this pathetic mess.
At some point, I break into weak sobbing.
I weep like a damn child.
What's worse, Rin's image is still burned in my mind.
Perhaps for good, I realize.
...I should have never written a single word, let alone a novel.
From the bottom of my heart, I wish I hadn't.
The sound chalk dragging across the blackboard echoes in the silent classroom.
Lifeless and wearisome, like me.
My hand keeps on writing out of pure habit.
I keep doing so for four classrooms, just like I've done for years.
Today as well...
I'll stay here, and keep repeating the usual routine. Without changing anything.
It feels wrong.
The sound of the chalk.
The heavy silence of the classroom.
I can't stay here a second longer.
Among these innocent students.
Even the rebellious heart of the worst behaved is so earnest that it becomes suffocating.
I can feel my hand tensing up as I hold the chalk.
It begins to tremble.
But I carry on writing.
The chalk breaks and falls to the floor.
I follow the small bits of chalk as they fall with my eyes.
I stay still for a moment.
I hear the whispers begin to spread behind my back.
How long will I keep doing this?
How long can I keep it up?
I glance at the wall clock.
It's almost time for the class to end.
I put down the broken chalk.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: It's a little early, but let's leave class here for today.
Some of the students who don't usually pay attention during class look at me with bulging eyes.
The buzz in the classroom grows even larger.
I just grab the attendance register, my bag, and get out at a brisk pace.
In all my years as a part-time teacher, I had never finished a class before the chime of the bell.
After all the classes are over...
I don't feel like going to the library or back home, so I end up in the smoking area.
Perhaps this is the only place that I have left now.
I take out a cig.
My very last one.
I light it up and pop it in my mouth.
I take out the note Rin gave me yesterday and look at it as I exhale smoke.
What place is this?
Rin said she's be waiting.
Is she waiting in this place?
Waiting for me to come?
...What if I go?
I'll probably become more miserable.
But...
She may be waiting for me for a long time if I don't.
I imagine her in strange place, standing all alone.
What do I do? What SHOULD I do? I...
While I dig myself into a mental hole, the cig burns out.
I'm left just staring at the ceiling.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Oh, you're coming here after class now, huh?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Yeah.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Give me one.
His eyes widen in pure surprise.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Did hell freeze over?
He fishes out a cig from the packet in his pocket and hands it over.
I take it, and light it up.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: I can't even remember the last time you ran out of them. This must be the first.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: That so?

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Yes, so!
His cigs are a lot blander than mine.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Not going to the library today?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Nah...

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: What happened?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Nothing.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Huh, really?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I have a regret.
Watanabe turns to me.
I just stare as the cig in my hand consumes itself.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I shouldn't have done something I'm not used to.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Not used to?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I wish I wouldn't have written that novel.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: ...Really?
I turn to Watanabe.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: I think I would have lots of fun if I could write stuff.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...Maybe people that can actually write feel that way.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Huh? Didn't you say you finished writing it?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ..Yeah, but...
I scratch at the back of my head.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...A student read it.
Watanabe freezes for a moment where he is.
He's silent, just staring at me.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...I was told that I didn't depict the person I was trying to evoke.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Tough crowd.
He lets out a hearty laugh.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: What? A little critic pulled the rug from under you?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: It's not as simple as you make it sound.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Maybe I really should start writing novels myself.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Wait, what?

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: I wanna get verbally abused by a student too.
I look up at him in disbelief.
But his expression is completely serious.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: I want to get stepped on.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: I'm joking, man.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I know.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: But what's so bad about it? It's kinda like being in a literature club, no?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: A 45-year old married teacher is too old for a club.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: What does age have to do with anything here?
I look up at him.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: I don't think the kind of guy that thinks his life is over after 40 would go and lose sleep over writing a novel over the last two weeks. No offense.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: You actually looked like alive as of late, minus the eye bags.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...Really?

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Yeah, you looked tired as hell.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Heh... Alive?

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Yeah.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: You still look that way, if you ask me.
Now I'm the one with wide eyes.
I thought I was on the bottom of the barrel...
But I look... alive?
Me?

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: You always had dead fish eyes, but now they're almost blazing.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Uh...

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: To be honest, I kinda of respect you for that. I mean, at that age people don't usually get stuff that makes them glow like that. Something they're crazy about, you know?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: We're about 10 years apart, though.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: I'm telling you it doesn't matter.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: I think the worry you had before about being unable to write was way worse. Don't you think?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I wonder. I feel a lot more tired now.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I lost my guide as soon as I came out of my comfort zone. You could say I'm worse off than before, in a way.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Mmh... So, what's the story anyway?
I look up at him again and wait.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: What's the novel about.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: A story I wrote with Hatano Shuho as the main character. He was a senior of mine in a writing seminar back in college.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Uuuuh, who?
Taken aback, I stare at him.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Hatano Rin's father. We talked about her at the bar, remember?

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Errr, what was it again? She's the daughter of some famous writer, right?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: You don't know about Hatano Shuho?

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Nah.
He shakes his head.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Not even a novel of him?

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Uuh, maybe?
I name some of his masterpieces for him.
But it doesn't seem like any of them ring a bell in his head.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: I've got no idea, huh?
I can't do anything but laugh.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Hey, no need to make fun of me.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: No, no, sorry. It just opened my eyes.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Huh?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Can't change the world, huh?

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: O-Okay? Uh, sorry?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Don't apologize, I think that helped me a whole lot. I may have been overthinking things.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Really? Anyway, I guess I see why you two talk so much now.
I turn to him again, curious.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: You knew her dad and all.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Oh, right.

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Guess that does put her in a good position to guide you.
Puzzled, I stare at him.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Guide?

texts.name: Watanabe
texts.text: Huh? Didn't you ask her to check your novel since she knew her dad?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Uh...
I take Rin's note out of my pocket again.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Guide, huh?
Hatano Shuho's daughter is my guide, then.
After I'm finished with work for the day, I head to the address she wrote down.
The address is in a neighboring town I can catch a bus to from my nearest station.
It reminds me of the first day we spoke.
I take another look at the note.
Her handwriting is very neat and prim.
I get off the bus as soon as my guide app tells me to, and then walk the rest of the way.
The designated place seems to be an elegant-looking low-rise condominium complex.
She's standing by the entrance.
She notices me and bows her head in a greeting.
Her expression seems pretty neutral the whole time.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Here?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: You'll understand when you come.
Rin says, before turning around and entering the complex.
This is a pretty fancy place. A unit here must cost a pretty penny.
She slowly walks down the hallway, then stops by a door and produces a key.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Hm?
She unlocks the door and goes inside.
I follow after her.
A collection of books covers the walls entirely.
And those that don't fit are piled up onto the desks or the floor.
The windows are crushed by the stacked bookshelves.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Do you, uh, live here?
She slowly shakes her head.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: My house is somewhere else. It's a short walk from here.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: This was my father's studio.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Whoa...
On closer inspection, there seems to be a good amount of notebooks besides the books.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Why bring me here?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Because he only was his true self in this place.
Rin says, as she picks up a notebook and hands it to me.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Can I... read it?
Rin simply nods.
I open the notebook.
Messy handwriting spreads across the pages.
This isn't writing...
It feels more like hatred being put to paper. Abuse and insults strewn about haphazardly in the paper.
Without a care for the delineated lines. It's like something a mad person would write in a frenzy of hate.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: What is this?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I don't know. I never really feel like looking into these books too much.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: This is the place where I met him for the last time.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: He hadn't gotten in contact for a long time, and calls from his work were coming in.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: And when I came here, he was already dead.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...Here?
I take another overview of the room.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: It was reported as a heart attack, though.
She slowly shakes her head.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: The bathtub was full of blood from his slashed wrist. It was already dry and black by the time I got here.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Suicide?
Rin nods.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: My father never... Hatano Shuho never saw me eye to eye, not even once.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: He died without ever being a father to me.
Rin walks into the room.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I don't have the courage to try and face the person he was, but...

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: The answer you're looking for is here.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Because the real Hatano Shuho was only truly alive when he was in this room.
Rin stops in front of the desk, and gently runs her fingers through the open laptop resting on it.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: That man was broken by a life of lies.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: He never was my father, not even in the end.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I think he couldn't accept his true self.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: That's why writing only served to drive him into a wall more and more.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Spinning words that didn't belong to anyone while never facing his true self.
She raises her face and turns to me.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: You can't follow after his footsteps.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I see it. You're so much like him.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: The version of my father you depicted was beautiful beyond words. Transparent, pure, and without an ounce of malice.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: But...

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: The last thing my real father wasn't the family he lost. He never thought of anyone but himself.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: If you came to know that Hatano Shuho, would you still write that?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Would you face the ugly, horrible person that he was?
As I stand there stunned looking back at her, tears begin welling in her eyes.
At that moment, I realize.
In her mind, that man that rejected reality and chose to die and me overlap. She sees him in me.
She realized that the words I was writing weren't coming from my heart when she read the Ginkgo story.
I stare back at her, without saying a word.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I'm still trapped by my father.
Rin murmurs, as she looks over the room.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I haven't left this room. Not really.
Our gazes meet and stay locked.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I haven't taken a step outside since the day I found his body.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Rin...

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Professor...
She calls out to me, holding back tears as her voice fades.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Save me, please...
